The chance to be a kid: protecting Colombian children in armed conflict; Access to justice: A big step for Malian women; “Feere diyara” (marketing has been good) for Sabati; Irrigation for food, better health, jobs and bringing people together; Family and community medicine: An asset in isolated regions of Mali; Dialogue, truth and reconciliation: The long road to peace in Mali; #FemParl IV: Inspiring action from the Middle East to South and Southeast Asia!; Did you know mathematics can help cocoa farmers adapt to the changing climate?; Building a National Textbook and Book Industry; Inclusive finance reaching financially excluded persons in Mali; Textbooks for Malian students; Local irrigation: Improving water management to boost agriculture and reduce poverty; In Mali: giving textbooks new life; SOLAR: A high-quality cold chain to improve the health of Mali's mothers and children; Canadian Support for the National Policy on Gender: Improving the Lives of Mali’s Women; SIGTAS: The Key to Modernizing Tax Administration in Mali; Office of the Auditor General of Mali; Grain commercialization by Malian cooperatives: A Market of the Future; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

HealthHealth CanadaImportation of US-Labelled Pancuronium Bromide Injection Due to Shortage of Neuromuscular Blocker Products - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-29https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72911a-eng.phpIssue; Who is affected; Report health or safety concerns; ImagesThere is an unprecedented demand and shortage of neuromuscular blocker (NMB) products in Canada as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.Pancuronium Bromide Injection, USP is a non-depolarizing NMB agent that is not authorized for use in Canada; however, Health Canada has permitted the exceptional importation and sale of this US-labelled product to mitigate shortages of NMB products in Canada.Main Covid-19 contentHealthcare Professionals

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaLast Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/last-mountain-lake.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; History; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationLast Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 165 km southeast of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. The MBS includes 4736 hectares of the north end of a large natural lake (Last Mountain Lake) and some of the adjacent uplands. It is within the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA) and located in the Moist Mixed-grass Prairie ecoregion of Saskatchewan.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicLast Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary

N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Fort Anne National Historic Siteen2020-04-02https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/ns/fortanne/activThings to doThe grassy Parade Square and impressive earthen ramparts of Fort Anne are mainly quiet today. But they have witnessed four centuries of tumultuous history. Inside the fort’s museum, housed inside a 1797 officers’ quarters, visitors can learn how Europe’s powers battled for the coveted site for literally hundreds of years. Outside, explore the fort’s defensive banks, moats and bastions and, after dark, take a guided, candlelit tour of the Garrison Graveyard.Contains Covid Alert

Canada and the worldGlobal Affairs CanadaThe Canada Fund for Local Initiatives - Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africaen2020-05-05https://www.international.gc.ca/world-monde/funding-financement/cfli-fcil/2020/south_africa-afrique_du_sud.aspx?lang=engProgram Description ; How to apply; General Information; Organizations eligible to apply for CFLI funding ; Thematic priorities ; COVID-19 Crisis ; Gender-based analysis  ; Eligible costsThe CFLI is a program designed to support small-scale, high-impact projects in developing countries that align with Global Affairs Canada’s thematic priority areas for engagement. The program is directed at projects conceived and designed predominantly by local partners. Projects are selected and approved by the relevant Canadian embassy or high commission. The CFLI also serves to support positive bilateral relations between Canada and recipient countries and their civil societies by deepening contacts and supporting local endeavours.Main Covid-19 content

N/ARoyal Canadian Air ForceNews Article | Henry J. Langdon: An RCAF, industry and union pioneeren2020-02-11http://www.rcaf-arc.forces.gc.ca/en/17-wing/news.page?doc=henry-j-langdon-an-rcaf-industry-and-union-pioneer%2Fk66hil9cNational Defence and the Canadian Armed Forces – COVID-19; More newsHenry Langdon enlisted in the RCAF in 1939, even though regulations did not permit the enlistment of Blacks. Working in predominantly white environments in the RCAF, Air Canada and in his union, he was highly respected for his abilities his efforts to improve race relations.News

A Dark Sky Preserve displays the science and stories of the stars. Aboriginal rock-art illuminates thousands of years of Mi’kmaw heritage. Interconnecting waterways and woodland trails lead paddlers and hikers through an ecosystem rich with wildlife. And the Atlantic coast reveals its beauty in Kejimkujik Seaside.Contains Covid Alert

Celebrating Canada’s 150th across Brazil; Kazakhstan celebrates 150 years of Canadian Confederation with star-packed Hockey Days; The Dominican Republic commemorates Canada’s 150th Anniversary of Confederation; Canada celebrates Capital Pride in Washington, D.C.; First Canada Day in Iraq in 20 years!; Canada 150 celebrated in Mongolia; Canada’s embassy in Poland transports virtual visitors at science show; Guatemala mission highlights CANADA 150 themes; Indonesia pushes the boat out to celebrate Canada150; Celebrating Canada in Belize; Canada 150 and Canadian Agrifood centre stage at leading Spanish trade show; Gifts that Give; Taking action on World Environment Day: tree-planting in Ankara, Turkey; Reproductive health care in Jordan - key to empowering women and girls; Thinking Green in Vietnam; Canada contributes to increasing access to justice in Mali and Ukraine; The Embassy of Canada to Chile held the second annual Cool Canada film festival, August 16 to 27, 2017; Preparing for a new reality – Indonesian fisherwomen adapt to the effects of climate change; Protecting religious rights in Indonesia; Inclusive Democratic Participation in Pakistan; Indigenous youth share their stories; Canada awards Bangladesh officials in the battle against Child, Early and Forced Marriage; Youth leaders tackle climate change at Model ASEAN; Canada Supports Strong Women through Education, Entrepreneurship; Passionate teen leads fight against FGM in Tanzania; Smashing tensions in Iraq, one volleyball tournament at a time; Language, the bridge builder in Iraq; From Iraq, with kisses; Promoting social cohesion in Iraq; Cleaning Up Daesh’s Explosive Legacy in Iraq; Empowering young Egyptian women to be entrepreneurs; From Isolation to Integration in Jordan; Supporting Venezuelan migrants in Brazil; Papua New Guinea: Helping women – helping communities; Colombian GBV survivors share their stories; How can you champion women’s rights?; M-SAWA project empowers small entrepreneurs: Gloria’s story; Shipping stability in a box to Iraq; Turning words to action in India’s fight for transgender rights; Food security in West Africa: a geographical issue; M-SAWA project: Kwale coconuts; Women activists fight to bridge the WikiGap; From Syria to the stage: Diana’s story; Sowing seeds for gender equality through agriculture in Côte d’Ivoire; Building gender equality in the Afghanistan police force; Helping local communities build trust in Mali; Canada champions LGBTQ2 rights across Asia-Pacific; Canada Day celebration in Chile highlights Diversity and Inclusion; Promoting freedom of the press in South Sudan; Breaking down barriers to celebrate LGBTI rights in Kazakhstan; In Tanzania, film is a powerful tool to end FGM; It takes a village: Addressing child, early and forced marriage in Côte d’Ivoire; Something to smile and sing about; “This is one of my favorite moments of the day”: School meals in Niger; “This is a new Afghanistan”: Women won’t be silenced; The women of the municipal police services of Lebanon are there to stay; The chance to be a kid: protecting Colombian children in armed conflict; Access to justice: A big step for Malian women; “Feere diyara” (marketing has been good) for Sabati; Irrigation for food, better health, jobs and bringing people together; Did you know mathematics can help cocoa farmers adapt to the changing climate?; Building a National Textbook and Book Industry; Inclusive finance reaching financially excluded persons in Mali; Textbooks for Malian students; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

N/AParole Board of CanadaParole Board of Canadaen2020-05-05https://www.canada.ca/en/parole-board.htmlFollow:; Contact us; Most requested; Services and information; Cannabis Record Suspensions; Expungement; Clemency (Royal Prerogative of Mercy); What we are doing; Corporate information; FeaturesThe Parole Board of Canada (PBC) is an independent administrative tribunal that, as part of the criminal justice system, makes quality conditional release and record suspension decisions, and clemency recommendations. The PBC contributes to the protection of society by facilitating, as appropriate, the timely reintegration of offenders as law-abiding citizens.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicParole Board of Canada

Question 12: Once repatriated, if volunteers are able to resume their contributions to the project, will an overhead allowance of 12% of a deemed $200 per day value continue to be paid to the recipient organization?; Family and community medicine: An asset in isolated regions of Mali; Dialogue, truth and reconciliation: The long road to peace in Mali; #FemParl IV: Inspiring action from the Middle East to South and Southeast Asia!; Did you know mathematics can help cocoa farmers adapt to the changing climate?; Building a National Textbook and Book Industry; Inclusive finance reaching financially excluded persons in Mali; Textbooks for Malian students; Local irrigation: Improving water management to boost agriculture and reduce poverty; In Mali: giving textbooks new life; SOLAR: A high-quality cold chain to improve the health of Mali's mothers and children; Canadian Support for the National Policy on Gender: Improving the Lives of Mali’s Women; SIGTAS: The Key to Modernizing Tax Administration in Mali; Office of the Auditor General of Mali; Grain commercialization by Malian cooperatives: A Market of the Future; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaGeorge C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/george-c-reifel.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about George C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationGeorge C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 5 km south of Vancouver, at the northern end of Westham Island in the Fraser River estuary. The sanctuary is named in honour of George C. Reifel, a nature enthusiast and conservationist who purchased land in the 1920s to create a private hunting retreat. Ownership was transferred to the Crown in the 1960s to create the MBS.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicGeorge C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary

HealthHealth CanadaImportation of US-Labelled Vecuronium Bromide for Injection due to Shortage of Neuromuscular Blocker Products - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-29https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72901a-eng.phpIssue; Who is affected; Report health or safety concerns; ImagesThere is an unprecedented demand and shortage of neuromuscular blocker (NMB) products in Canada as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the medical necessity of NMBs, Health Canada has added US-labelled Vecuronium Bromide for Injection 10mg in a fliptop vial (1 mg/mL when reconstituted to 10 mL) to the List of Drugs for Exceptional Importation and Sale.Main Covid-19 contentHealthcare Professionals

It is an extremely isolated location, and access to it is determined by constraints of weather and geography. Visitor experience opportunities are similar to other remote national parks in Canada, where there are few visitor facilities and the wilderness of the site constitutes an important feature of the experience.Contains Covid Alert

N/AParks Canada AgencyPlan your visit - Sirmilik National Parken2020-03-17https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/sirmilik/visitPlan your visitSpread across 22,000 square kilometres (13,665 square miles) of Baffin Island’s northeastern coast, Sirmilik is divided into three sections - Bylot Island, Oliver Sound and Borden Peninsula. It is renowned for its rich array of wildlife, from lemmings and polar bears to whales and more than 70 bird species. It is one of the most accessible parks in Nunavut.Contains Covid Alert

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaAmherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-31https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/amherst-point.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; History; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Amherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationAmherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) lies five km southwest of Amherst at the head of the Bay of Fundy. It was established in 1947 with the agreement of the landowners. However, to afford permanent habitat protection, the land was later acquired by the Canadian Wildlife Service (1973–1974) and designated as a component of the Chignecto National Wildlife Area. The landscape is a mosaic of ponds, marshes, forests and old farm fields.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicAmherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuary

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

HealthHealth CanadaChloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can have serious side effects. These drugs should be used only under the supervision of a physician. - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-25https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72885a-eng.phpSummary; Issue; What you should do; What industry professionals should do; Media enquiries; Public enquiriesOttawa – Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine may cause serious side effects, including serious heart rhythm problems. The risk of these side effects may increase at higher doses, or if the drugs are used in combination with other drugs, such as the antibiotic azithromycin. Patients should use these drugs only under the supervision of a physician. Health Canada is concerned that some people may be directly buying and using chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine to prevent or treat COVID-19 without a prescription.Main Covid-19 contentGeneral Public

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Join a guided tour or explore the various sites within the fort on your own. Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaMigratory Game Bird Hunting Permiten2020-05-04https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-game-bird-hunting/permit.htmlNoticeThe Migratory Game Bird Hunting Permits are now available for the 2015 hunting season and are valid until March 10th, 2016 during open season (also valid until July 31st, 2016 for specified overabundant species). Environment Canada is pleased to announce that starting this year a full electronic permitting system will enable Canadian and international hunters to buy permits online and print them from home. Permits are also available for purchase at Canada Post outlets and through some independent vendors. If you have any questions with regards to the availability of the Migratory Game Bird Hunting Permits at a postal outlet, you can contact Canada Post customer service at 1-866-607-6301.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicMigratory Game Bird Hunting Permit

N/AParks Canada AgencyKejimkujik National Park and National Historic Siteen2020-03-27https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ns/kejimkujikThere are many sides to Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site. Inland, old growth hemlock, sugar maple and yellow aspen trees border warm-water lakes with quartzite shores. Kejimkujik Seaside, a separate landscape, juxtaposes with colourful barrens, granite cobbles and white-sand beaches. The land also tells the tale of the Mi’kmaw, carved in stone and illuminated through story and legend. Paddle the waters, hike the trails and discover the rich diversity of Kejimkujik.Contains Covid Alert

Arts and heritage organizations may apply for up to $5,000 to organize a collaborative problem-solving activity which seeks to address a common business purpose.Contains Covid AlertThe First Spark Initiative – Strategic Initiatives

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

N/AParks Canada AgencyVisitor safety - Quttinirpaaq National Parken2020-03-27https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/quttinirpaaq/securite-safetyVisitor safetyOn Ellesmere Island, less than 800 kilometres (500 miles) from the North Pole, Quttinirpaaq is the world’s northernmost national park. If heading into the park, it is essential to be self-sufficient and experienced. Individual travellers are welcome, though most visitors arrive with an outfitter for one or two weeks of outdoor activities like hiking, skiing, mountain climbing or traversing ice caps and glaciers.Contains Covid Alert

Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

HealthHealth CanadaImportation of US-Labelled Rocuronium Bromide Injection Due to Shortage of Canadian-labelled Rocuronium - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-05-01https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72907a-eng.phpIssue; Who is affected; Report health or safety concerns; ImagesThere is an unprecedented demand and shortage of Rocuronium Bromide Injection in Canada as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the medical necessity of this product, Health Canada has added US-labelled Rocuronium Bromide Injection 100 mg/10 mL (10 mg/mL) vials in a 10 mL volume to the List of Drugs for Exceptional Importation and Sale in accordance with the Interim Order.Main Covid-19 contentHealthcare Professionals

N/AParks Canada AgencyWrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Siteen2020-03-20https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/nu/epaveswrecksIn 1845, explorer Sir John Franklin set sail from England with two ships, HMS Erebus and HMS Terror, in search of a Northwest Passage across what is now Canada's Arctic. The ships and crews vanished, prompting a massive search that continues to this day. A breakthrough was made in September 2014 when an expedition led by Parks Canada discovered the wreck of HMS Erebus. This discovery lead to the creation of the Wrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site of Canada.Contains Covid Alert

N/AParks Canada AgencyQausuittuq National Parken2020-03-20https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/qausuittuqQausuittuq National ParkImagine a cluster of islands in a frozen sea, a home for the endangered Peary caribou, a traditional hunting and fishing area that has sustained Inuit of Resolute Bay since the time of their relocation in the 1950’s; Qausuittuq National Park is all of that and more.Contains Covid Alert
Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/vaseux-lake.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Vaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 5 km south of Okanagan Falls on Highway 97 in the Okanagan Valley of southern British Columbia. Vaseux Lake is in the Osoyoos-Arid Biotic Area, which is a northern extension of the Great Basin Desert.The MBS was originally established to provide protection to Trumpeter Swans. Canada Geese use the site extensively and nest in numbers exceeding 200 on Hatfield Island.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary

Celebrating Canada’s 150th across Brazil; Kazakhstan celebrates 150 years of Canadian Confederation with star-packed Hockey Days; The Dominican Republic commemorates Canada’s 150th Anniversary of Confederation; Canada celebrates Capital Pride in Washington, D.C.; First Canada Day in Iraq in 20 years!; Canada 150 celebrated in Mongolia; Canada’s embassy in Poland transports virtual visitors at science show; Guatemala mission highlights CANADA 150 themes; Indonesia pushes the boat out to celebrate Canada150; Celebrating Canada in Belize; Canada 150 and Canadian Agrifood centre stage at leading Spanish trade show; Gifts that Give; Taking action on World Environment Day: tree-planting in Ankara, Turkey; Reproductive health care in Jordan - key to empowering women and girls; Thinking Green in Vietnam; Canada contributes to increasing access to justice in Mali and Ukraine; The Embassy of Canada to Chile held the second annual Cool Canada film festival, August 16 to 27, 2017; Preparing for a new reality – Indonesian fisherwomen adapt to the effects of climate change; Protecting religious rights in Indonesia; Inclusive Democratic Participation in Pakistan; Indigenous youth share their stories; Canada awards Bangladesh officials in the battle against Child, Early and Forced Marriage; Youth leaders tackle climate change at Model ASEAN; Canada Supports Strong Women through Education, Entrepreneurship; Canada and Finland mark Sámi National Day by discussing Indigenous education; Empowering women and protecting the environment through waste management; Canadian cleantech companies expand profile and shrink environmental footprint; Passionate teen leads fight against FGM in Tanzania; Smashing tensions in Iraq, one volleyball tournament at a time; Language, the bridge builder in Iraq; From Iraq, with kisses; Promoting social cohesion in Iraq; Cleaning Up Daesh’s Explosive Legacy in Iraq; Empowering young Egyptian women to be entrepreneurs; From Isolation to Integration in Jordan; Supporting Venezuelan migrants in Brazil; Papua New Guinea: Helping women – helping communities; Colombian GBV survivors share their stories; How can you champion women’s rights?; M-SAWA project empowers small entrepreneurs: Gloria’s story; Shipping stability in a box to Iraq; Turning words to action in India’s fight for transgender rights; Food security in West Africa: a geographical issue; M-SAWA project: Kwale coconuts; Women activists fight to bridge the WikiGap; From Syria to the stage: Diana’s story; Sowing seeds for gender equality through agriculture in Côte d’Ivoire; Building gender equality in the Afghanistan police force; Helping local communities build trust in Mali; Canada champions LGBTQ2 rights across Asia-Pacific; Canada Day celebration in Chile highlights Diversity and Inclusion; Promoting freedom of the press in South Sudan; Breaking down barriers to celebrate LGBTI rights in Kazakhstan; In Tanzania, film is a powerful tool to end FGM; It takes a village: Addressing child, early and forced marriage in Côte d’Ivoire; Something to smile and sing about; “This is one of my favorite moments of the day”: School meals in Niger; “This is a new Afghanistan”: Women won’t be silenced; The women of the municipal police services of Lebanon are there to stay; The chance to be a kid: protecting Colombian children in armed conflict; Access to justice: A big step for Malian women; “Feere diyara” (marketing has been good) for Sabati; Irrigation for food, better health, jobs and bringing people together; Family and community medicine: An asset in isolated regions of Mali; Dialogue, truth and reconciliation: The long road to peace in Mali; #FemParl IV: Inspiring action from the Middle East to South and Southeast Asia!; Did you know mathematics can help cocoa farmers adapt to the changing climate?; Building a National Textbook and Book Industry; Inclusive finance reaching financially excluded persons in Mali; Textbooks for Malian students; Local irrigation: Improving water management to boost agriculture and reduce poverty; In Mali: giving textbooks new life; SOLAR: A high-quality cold chain to improve the health of Mali's mothers and children; Canadian Support for the National Policy on Gender: Improving the Lives of Mali’s Women; SIGTAS: The Key to Modernizing Tax Administration in Mali; Office of the Auditor General of Mali; Grain commercialization by Malian cooperatives: A Market of the Future; Mali's university community health centres: A partnership between communities; Indigenous health and well being: Youth lead call for change; Canada highlights women's work for gender equality in Colombia; Standing together to end gender-based violence in Zimbabwe; Diversity is strength: Creating space for peace and inclusion in Côte d'Ivoire; Combatting plastic waste in Vietnam: An action plan for a more sustainable future; Women in the media: Agents of peace in Georgia; Vive la Educación! Improving access to education for Colombian kids; International leaders stand up for gender equality in The Hague; Acceptance: Crucial for ending discrimination against Timor-Leste’s LGBTI community; Composting towards equality: Women join the workforce in Jordan; Women driving buses? Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 content

N/ACanadian Trade Commissioner ServiceChina Food and Drinks Fair (CFDF) 2020en2020-03-11https://www.tradecommissioner.gc.ca/china-chine/events-evenements/0009466.aspx?lang=engCoronavirus disease (COVID-19);  Canada Pavilion wants you!; Registration; Contacts; Why your organization should participate:; Trade Commissioner(s) involvement:CFDF is a national level annual trading fair that has been running since 1955, and is considered as the largest and most influential trade fair in China's food and alcohol industry. CFDF is held every March in Chengdu, with another stop in another city in the fall. CFDF attracts over 4,000 companies from 20 countries and is attended by over 400,000 visitors with more than half of the participants traveling from the East, North and South parts of China. The fair has exhibition halls focusing on wine and spirits, Chinese liquor, food, beverage, seasoning, food machinery and packaging.Contains Covid Alert

N/AParks Canada AgencyFort Anne National Historic Siteen2020-03-20https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/ns/fortanneStep foot onto Canada’s oldest National Historic Site and one of the most hotly contested pieces of land on the entire continent at Fort Anne. For centuries, a succession of Scottish, French, First Nations and English settlers clashed over this prize on the banks of Nova Scotia’s Annapolis River. Today, visitors can walk the earthen walls, explore the 1797 Officers’ Quarters Museum and soak up centuries of Canadian history.Contains Covid Alert

HealthHealth CanadaUnauthorized test kits claiming to diagnose or detect COVID-19 put your health at risk - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-05-07https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/73003a-eng.phpSummary; Issue; What you should do; Media enquiries; Public enquiriesOTTAWA – Health Canada is warning Canadians not to buy home diagnostic test kits, including mail-in sample collection kits, claiming to diagnose or detect COVID-19 because they may provide inaccurate or false results. These products have not been authorized by Health Canada, which means they have not been reviewed for safety, quality or effectiveness.Main Covid-19 contentGeneral Public

N/AE DivisionRCMP in British Columbia - 2020 Junior Mountie Police Academy postponed indefinitely due to Covid-19en2020-04-29http://burnaby.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/ViewPage.action?contentId=64223&languageId=1&siteNodeId=20872020 Junior Mountie Police Academy postponed indefinitely due to Covid-19Main Covid-19 content

Use this form to submit corrections or comments on this row in the inventory. Comments will be reviewed by DTO

Web Content Inventory Instructions

The COVID-19 Web content inventory tool relies on data from two sources:

  • Canada.ca search results
  • AEM web crawl

We aim to update the tool daily.

You can use the tool to validate and improve metadata. You can also identify:

  • what COVID-19 content exists for a particular theme or department
  • duplication or overlap
  • out-of-date materials

Tool use examples

These examples show specific uses for validation of content and updates to metadata.

E.g. The Benefits theme lead wants to ensure there are no out-dated alerts

  • On the left side of the page, select Benefits in the theme drop down
  • Select “alerts” for content type
  • Click “Filter” button to show results
  • Click and hold the URL column header and reposition it to the left of the page title
  • Select each page URL to verify that the alerts are still accurate

E.g. The Department of Finance wants to ensure their COVID-19 pages are following the metadata guidance for titles

  • On the left side of the page, select Department of Finance in the departments list
  • Click the filter button to show results
  • Click and hold the TITLE column and move it to the right of the Department column
  • A review of results shows COVID appears in some cases, but not all
  • Click the “Excel” button towards the top of the page to download a spreadsheet of these results
  • Use the spreadsheet to provide clear instructions to the department content manager

Considerations

  • The tool is available in English and French
  • The left side of the page provides the main site filters – theme, department and four types of content:
  • Main COVID-19 content returns pages that include substantive information on health, economics, restrictions, etc. Generally, pages accessible from Canada.ca/covid19 are “main COVID-19” content.
  • Alerts returns pages that include an visual and textual alert, with some content related to COVID-19, usually in relation to a service interruption.
  • Links returns pages that include a link to a page with COVID-19 content
  • News returns 5 types of news releases and announcements, including:
    • backgrounders
    • media advisories
    • news releases
    • speeches
    • statements
  • The columns can be rearranged by clicking, holding and dragging them to the position you want The toggles at the top of the page give you additional control over what you see Use the Filter reset button if your results are not what you expected

Generate an Excel report for internal use

To generate an Excel report:

  • Use the filter tool, to get the results you want,
  • click the Excel button.
  • Use the comments column in the Excel report to indicate changes or questions for your web team, program area or communications team

This may be useful for:

  • corrections
  • removal or archiving of pages
  • adding new pages to your cluster

Submit comments to the Digital Transformation Office (DTO)

To submit comments about a specific page to the DTO, click the Submit button in the Comments column for that page in the inventory tool. Comments are sent to: dto.btn@tbs-sct.gc.ca

Comments will help us to complete a QA on the tool. Right now we see this tool as an alpha release, there are improvements and corrections required.
